bibl.title: Notes of an interview with Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 21, 1929

div1.p: The interview centers on Kean's reluctance to give credit to the work done by Roger Ames during the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Notes of an interview with Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 21, 1929
div1.opener:
From Mrs Ames
Washington, D. C.
October 21, 1929.
div1.p:
A call upon Colonel Kean in re the recognition
of Doctor Roger Post Ames' services in stamping out Yellow Fever
through experimentation in Cuba elicited the following facts and
produced the following impressions:

Colonel Kean was most friendly. He said that the
move for recognition of soliders was the result of a school teacher
in New York who became interested because of a soldier - Kissinger;
that he and the Surgeon General in conference with and by request
of the committee (possibly Committee on Military Affairs) had de-
cided to fix a rigid rule and that rule should say that only those
who offered their bodies and those who did the scientific work
should be recognized. That definitely Doctor Roger Post Ames did
not fall into either cales. When asked whether the experiment could
have been carried on if these others, the surgeons and nurses had
not been willing to do the work, he said it could not have been done
at all without them. He added hastily, “had they not been willing
to do their duty.” He either forgot to answer or evaded answering
the question when asked what other surgeons beside Doctor Ames were
actually in charge of the camp. He said he had secured money to
carry out the experiment but he Major Kean had not been in charge of the camp.
Doctor Ames had been in charge but whether or not alone he did not
answer.

He showed a book “Senate Document” No. 823 - 81st
Congress Third Session, “Yellow Fever” - a Compilation of Various
Publications, the title of which he wrote down. In this book there
was a statement saying that Doctor Ames had been asked to diagnose
the mysterious case for so long known as XY - and that Doctor Ames
had pronounced the case undoubtedly Yellow Fever. This showed that
Doctor Ames was not just an ordinary surgeon as to Yellow Fever.
(Major Reed sent for Doctor Ames) He told of his surprise when
his attention was called to the fact that Doctor Ames was not an
immune and had actually had Yellow Fever in February, 1901. He
was dubious about its being really Yellow Fever since it was at
a time when few cases occurred and Doctor Ames was in the hospital
such a short time. He admitted that it was in the record right
enough and that Major Alex Stark certified to it as such. He
said that he would not take the responsibility of saying who should
or who should not be given recognition and that if the committee
saw fit to include those who did the hospital service Doctor Ames
would be the first to come in. He said over a hundred had sought
recognition. He said that at the time the Committee asked for a
ruling to guide them, the Surgeon General had called him in and
that the division had been made without regard to who would or
would not be included. Some thought he should be included but
he did not.

The only places where Colonel Kean left impress-
ions different to the facts stated above was when asked what other
doctors actually had charge of the camp beside Doctor Ames. He
appeared to evade that question. He did not answer and because
he appeared to evade, it was not pressed. He was uncomfortable
about the fact that Doctor Ames was not an immune. He said
that certainly they were under the impression that he was an im-
mune and certainly he believed Doctor Ames thought he was an im-
mune. He seemed to want to cast either some doubt on the veracity
of the person certifying; or on Doctor Ames; or in some way imply
that something either mysterious or discreditable attached to it
(see interview with General Ireland). The impression also was
left that in this point lies the weakness of the refusal to give
recognition to Doctor Ames' services. If this point is pushed,
it will be found the source of their embarrassment. They are
doing a good man a real injustice. Colonel Kean was plainly un-
easy and restless when this fact of non-immunity on the part of
Doctor Ames was brought up.
